questions.title: Passage Ⅰ
questions.article:
A science class studied the frictional forces involving moving surfaces.

In each of the following experiments, the students used identical bricks that were either unwrapped or that were securely wrapped in paper. The students tied a string around a brick, fastened a spring scale to the string, and pulled the brick across a table, as shown in Figure 1.


The amount of the force, in newtons (N), required to move the brick across the table at a constant speed was measured on the spring scale. This value equaled the amount of the frictional force between the brick and the tabletop.

(Note: A brick's facets consist of 2 faces, 2 sides, and 2 ends, as shown in Figure 2. Unless otherwise stated, each brick lay on one of its faces. Also, unless otherwise stated, all bricks were pulled across the table at the same low speed.)


Experiment 1
Four bricks were each wrapped in a different type of paper. Each wrapped brick was pulled across the table. The measured forces are given in Table 1.


Experiment 2
The brick that was wrapped in brown paper was pulled across the table while the brick lay on a face, a side, and an end (see Table 2).


Experiment 3
An unwrapped brick was pulled across the table. The procedure was repeated with 1, 2, 3, or 4 identical unwrapped bricks stacked facedown on top of the first unwrapped brick (see Table 3).


Experiment 4
The brick that was wrapped in brown paper was pulled across the table at a constant medium speed and then at a constant high speed (see Table 4).
questions.question: 1.  Which of the following ranks the different types  of paper used to wrap the bricks in order, from the paper that presented the least resistance  to sliding  to  the paper that presented the greatest resistance to sliding?

choices.A: Brown paper, newspaper, notebook paper, waxed paper
choices.B: Newspaper, notebook paper, brown paper, waxed paper
choices.C: Notebook paper, waxed paper, brown paper, newspaper
choices.D: Waxed paper, notebook paper, newspaper, brown paper

questions.title: Passage Ⅰ
questions.article:

Experiment 2

Experiment 3

Experiment 4
The brick that was wrapped in brown paper was pulled across the table at a constant medium speed and then at a constant high speed (see Table 4).
questions.question: 2.  In Experiment 1, the  reason  the students  wrapped bricks in different kinds of paper was most likely to vary the amount of frictional force between the:

choices.A: wrapping papers and the bricks.
choices.B: wrapped bricks and the tabletop.
choices.C: wrapped bricks and the string used to pull the bricks.
choices.D: stacked bricks, so that the bricks would not slide over each other when they were pulled across the table.

questions.question: 3.  If the procedure used in Experiment 3  had been repeated with a stack of  unwrapped bricks, the amount of force required for the stack  to  be  pulled across the table at the low speed  most likely  would have been closest to which of the following?

questions.question: 4.  Suppose the students had placed the 4 wrapped bricks used in Experiment 1 on the table and shoved each of these bricks, causing  the bricks  to slide along  the table at the same initial speed. Based on the results of Experiment 1, the brick wrapped in which paper would most likely have taken the  lease amount  of  time  to come to a complete stop?

choices.A: Brown paper
choices.B: Newspaper
choices.C: Notebook paper
choices.D: Waxed paper

questions.question: 5.  Based on the results of Experiments 1 and 4, what was the effect, if any, of  a  brick's speed  on the amount  of the frictional force on the brick?

choices.A: The amount of the frictional force always increased as the brick's speed increased.
choices.B: The amount of the frictional force always decreased as the brick's speed increased.
choices.C: The amount of the frictional force decreased and then increased as the brick's speed increased.
choices.D: The amount of the frictional force was not affected by the brick's speed.

questions.question: 6.  The main  purpose of  Experiment  3  was to  determine the dependence of the amount of the frictional force on which of the following variables?

choices.A: The mass of a wrapped brick
choices.B: The weight of the stack of bricks
choices.C: The type of paper used to wrap the stacked bricks
choices.D: The amount of force exerted on the stacked bricks by the spring scale

questions.title: Passage Ⅱ
questions.article:
High concentrations of fecal coliforms in the water of a lake are a hazard to humans swimming in the lake. Fecal coliforms are bacteria found in the intestines of all endothermic animals. Two studies in 2001 examined fecal coliform concentrations in surface water samples from a large freshwater lake and its tributary streams.

Study 1
Around 10 A.M. on Monday of every week in June, July, and August, 100 mL water samples were collected from 3 separate locations within the area of the lake desig­nated for swimming. The samples were analyzed to deter­mine the average fecal coliform concentration, in colony-forming units (CFU) per 100 mL (see Figure 1). A CFU value is the number of distinct colonies formed on a growth plate by the bacteria in a sample after the sample has been placed on the growth plate and incubated for 24 hr.


Study 2
In July, on the last of 14 consecutive days of fair weather, 100 mL water samples were collected from each of the following sites—the designated swimming area, 6 lake sites that were outside the designated swimming area, and each of the lake's 5 tributary streams. Several 100 g samples of sand from the beach at the designated swimming area were also collected. A second set of samples was collected at the same sites on a rainy July day, the last of 7 consecutive days of rain. The samples were analyzed to determine the average fecal coliform concen­tration (see Figure 2). The heavy, dashed, horizontal line in Figure 2 represents the fecal coliform water quality stan­dard for the lake. If the average fecal coliform concentra­tion for water samples collected from the lake on a particular day exceeds chis level, all swimming in the lake is prohibited for that day.


Figures 1 and 2 adapted from Michele Zimmerman, "Occurrence of Bacteria in Blue Marsh Lake and Selected Tributaries, Berks County, Pennsylvania: September-October 2001." ©2002 by the United States Geological Survey.
questions.question: 7.  According to the results of Study 1, the increase in the average fecal coliform concentration for water samples from   the   designated    swimming   area    was   greatest between which of the following dates?

choices.A: June 11 and June 18
choices.B: June 25 and July 2
choices.C: July 30 and August 6
choices.D: August 20 and August 27

questions.question: 8.  Assume  that  each  fecal  coliform  bacterium   forms a single,  distinct  colony  on   a  growth   plate  during the sample analysis. Given  the results of Study  1, to pro­duce the results shown for the June 18 samples, those 100 mL water samples had to  contain,  on  average, approximately how many fecal coliform bacteria?

questions.question: 9.  Given the information about Study 2, which of the following statements best explains why the dashed, horizontal line in Figure 2 does not extend across the bars for the samples from the beach at the designated swimming area?

choices.A: The standard applies to both endothermic and ectothermic animals.
choices.B: The standard was established for both sand and water samples.
choices.C: The standard was established for water samples only.
choices.D: The standard applies only during the winter.

questions.question: 10.  Which of the following hypotheses was most likely being tested in Study 2 ?

choices.A: The fecal coliform concentration varies with the depth of the lake water.
choices.B: The fecal coliform concentration varies with the pH of the lake water.
choices.C: More fecal coliforms enter the lake during rainy weather than during fair weather.
choices.D: More fecal coliforms enter the lake during July than during August.

questions.question: 11.  Would the presence of large numbers of geese in and around the designated swimming area throughout the summer of 2001 likely have had any effect on the fecal coliform concentrations measured in the studies?

choices.A: No, because geese are not endothermic and are not a source of fecal coliforms.
choices.B: No, because geese are endothermic and are not a source of fecal coliforms.
choices.C: Yes, because geese are not endothermic and are a source of fecal coliforms.
choices.D: Yes , because geese are endothermic and are a source of fecal coliforms.

questions.question: 12.  A comparison of the average fecal coliform concentra­tions given in Figure 2 for the fair-weather samples shows that, relative to the concentration for the tribu­tary streams, the concentration  for the lake sites outside the designated swimming area was approximately:

choices.A: as high.
choices.B: as high.
choices.C: 10 times as high.
choices.D: 100 times as high.

questions.title: Passage Ⅲ
questions.article:
A mole is 6 x 1023 molecules or formula units of a compound. Thus, the number of sucrose molecules in 1 mole of sucrose equals the number of NaCl units in 1 mole of NaCl. Molality (m) is a unit of concentration defined as:


When a substance is dissolved in a solvent, the freez­ing and boiling points of the solution will differ from those of the pure solvent. These changes depend on the concentration­ show how the freezing point and the boiling point, respec­tively, of H2O at 1 atm of pressure vary with concentration for 3 solutes.
questions.question: 13.  Based on the trends in Figure 2, which of the following aqueous   solutions   would    have   the   highest    boiling point ?

choices.A: 1.20 m CaCl2
choices.B: 1.40 m NaCl
choices.C: 1.60 m sucrose
choices.D: 1.80 m sucrose

choices.A: Freezing point
choices.B: Boiling point
choices.C: Molar mass

questions.question: 16.  Based on Figure 1, as the mass of sucrose dissolved  in a given amount of solvent increases, the freezing point of the solution will:

choices.A: increase linearly.
choices.B: increase, but not linearly.
choices.C: decrease linearly.
choices.D: decrease, but not linearly.

questions.question: 17.  A student claimed that, per formula unit, adding NaCl changes the boiling point of H2O more than  adding CaCl2. Does Figure 2 support this claim?

choices.A: No; at a given concentration, NaCl caused a smaller increase in the boiling point.
choices.B: No; at a given concentration, NaCl caused a smaller decrease in the boiling point.
choices.C: Yes; at a given concentration, NaCl caused a greater increase in the boiling point.
choices.D: Yes; at a given concentration, NaCl caused a greater decrease in the boiling point.

questions.title: Passage Ⅳ
questions.article:
Wind spread ash from a volcanic eruption eastward over a large area. An ash sample was collected at each of 5 different distances east of the volcano. The diameters of the particles in each sample were determined and con­verted to phi (see Table 1). Figure 1 shows the weight percent of each sample's ash particles belonging in each of 10 different ranges of phi (see Figure 1).





†Weight percent is the percent of a sample's weight from particles having diameters in a given range as defined in Table 1.

Figure 1

Figure 2 shows the weight percents of the 4 types of ash particles—rock fragments, glass shards , feldspar crys­tals, and mafic crystals (various iron magnesium silicate compounds)—in 13 ash samples, each collected at a differ­ent distance east of the volcano.


†Weight percent is the percent of a sample's weight from particles of a specific type.

Figure 2

Figures 2 adapted from Steven Carey and Haraldur Sigurdsson, "Influence of Particle Aggregation on Deposition of Distal Tephra from the May 18, 1980, Eruption of Mount St. Helens Volcano." ©1982 by the American Geophysical Union.
questions.question: 18.  Figure 2 indicates that, compared with the sample col­lected closest to the volcano, the sample collected far­thest from the volcano contained higher weight percents of:

choices.A: rock fragments and glass shards only.
choices.B: rock fragments and feldspar crystals only.
choices.C: glass shards and feldspar crystals only.
choices.D: glass shards and mafic crystals only.

Figure 2

Figures 2 adapted from Steven Carey and Haraldur Sigurdsson, "Influence of Particle Aggregation on Deposition of Distal Tephra from the May 18, 1980, Eruption of Mount St. Helens Volcano." ©1982 by the American Geophysical Union.
questions.question: 19.  According to Figure 2, rock fragments in the ash sample collected at 160 km east of the volcano com­prised approximately what percent of the sample's weight?

questions.title: Passage Ⅳ
questions.article:
Wind spread ash from a volcanic eruption eastward over a large area. An ash sample was collected at each of 5 different distances east of the volcano. The diameters of the particles in each sample were determined and con­verted to phi (see Table 1). Figure 1 shows the weight percent of each sample's ash particles belonging in each of 10 different ranges of phi (see Figure 1).





†Weight percent is the percent of a sample's weight from particles having diameters in a given range as defined in Table 1.

Figure 1

Figure 2 shows the weight percents of the 4 types of ash particles—rock fragments, glass shards , feldspar crys­tals, and mafic crystals (various iron magnesium silicate compounds)—in 13 ash samples, each collected at a differ­ent distance east of the volcano.


†Weight percent is the percent of a sample's weight from particles of a specific type.

Figure 2

Figures 2 adapted from Steven Carey and Haraldur Sigurdsson, "Influence of Particle Aggregation on Deposition of Distal Tephra from the May 18, 1980, Eruption of Mount St. Helens Volcano." ©1982 by the American Geophysical Union.
questions.question: 20.  Based  on  Figures 1 and 2, the  majority of the ash  parti­cles in the sample collected  405 km east of  the  volcano were:

choices.A: mafic crystals that have diameters corresponding to phi values less than 2.
choices.B: mafic crystals that have diameters corresponding to phi values greater than or equal to 2.
choices.C: glass shards that have diameters corresponding to phi values less than 2.
choices.D: glass shards that have diameters corresponding to phi values greater than or equal to 2.

questions.question: 22.  A student claimed  that  if  the  ash  particles  in  the sample collected closest to the  volcano  are compared with those in the sample collected farthest from the volcano, the weight percent of larger particles will be higher in  the sample collected  closest  to the volcano. Is this claim supported by Table 1 and Figure 1 ?

choices.A: No; the weight percent of 0-3 phi particles was lower 27 km east of the volcano than it was 405 km east of the volcano.
choices.B: No; the weight percent of 7-9 phi particles was lower 27 km east of the volcano than it was 405 km east of the volcano.
choices.C: Yes; the weight percent of 0-3 phi particles was higher 27 km east of the volcano than it was 405 km east of the volcano.
choices.D: Yes; the weight percent of 7-9 phi particles was higher 27 km east of the volcano than it was 405 km east of the volcano.

questions.title: Passage Ⅴ
questions.article:
Four researchers performed the following experiment to investigate changes in snowshoe hare populations in a coniferous forest over an 8 yr period.

Experiment
The researchers selected a 10 km x 10 km study area. Twenty-five 1 km x 1 km plots were then mapped out within this study area, so that none of the plots was in direct contact with another plot. Each plot was then assigned to 1 of 5 treatments, as shown in Table 1.


Each plot was surveyed during the month of April and the population density of snowshoe hares, in hares/hectare, was calculated. A hectare is 10,000 m2. Table 2 shows the average population density of the plots assigned to Treat­ment 1.


For each year, the researchers defined the population density ratio for a given treatment as being equal to the value of the following expression:


Figure 1 shows the population density ratio for Treat­ments 2-5.


Tables and figure adapted from Charles K. Krebs et al., "Impact of Food and Predation on the Snowshoe Hare Cycle." ©1995 by the American Association for the Advancement of Science.
questions.question: 23.  Which of the following most likely explains why the researchers included Treatment 1 in the experiment?

choices.A: Treatment 1 acted as a standard of comparison to determine how the other experimental treatments affected population density.
choices.B: Treatment 1 provided a means of estimating the maximum number of snowshoe hares that can survive on a 1 km x 1 km plot.
choices.C: Treatment 1 was designed to determine the amount of food that should be added to the plots that were assigned to Treatment 5.
choices.D: Treatment 1 helped the researchers determine the type s of food eaten by snowshoe hares over the course of a year.

choices.A: Hawks
choices.B: Snowshoe hares
choices.C: Wolves
choices.D: Snakes

questions.question: 25.  Treatment 3 was most likely included  in  the experi­ment to investigate which of the following questions?

choices.A: What types of plants do snowshoe hares typically consume in natural environments?
choices.B: What types of organisms compete with snowshoe hares for vegetation?
choices.C: Does the application of a fertilizer increase the growth rate of vegetation in forest plots containing snowshoe hares?
choices.D: Does an increase in the mass of vegetation in a plot affect the population density of snowshoe hares?

questions.question: 26.  Prior  to   performing   the  experiment,  each  of   the 4 researchers proposed 1 of the following hypothesis. Which hypothesis is best supported by the results?

choices.A: Adding food to the plots will not affect the popula­tion density of the snowshoe hares.
choices.B: Adding food to the plots will increase snowshoe hare populations more than will adding fertilizer to the plots.
choices.C: Excluding predators from the plots will not affect the population density of the snowshoe hares.
choices.D: Excluding predators from the plots will increase snowshoe hare populations less than will adding fertilizer to the plots.

choices.D: Treatment 5, Treatment 4, Treatment 3, Treatment 2

questions.question: 28.  Two treatments are synergistic if the effect of combin­ing the treatments exceeds the sum of the effects of each treatment individually. The design of the experiment allowed the researchers to investigate whether which of the following pairs of treatments are synergistic?

choices.A: Treatments 2 and 3
choices.B: Treatments 2 and 4
choices.C: Treatments 3 and 4
choices.D: Treatments 3 and 5

questions.title: Passage Ⅵ
questions.article:
Ozone (O3) is concentrated in a part of Earth's atmo­sphere called the ozone layer. O3 absorbs harmful high­-energy solar radiation. Unusually low amounts of O3 have been detected over Antarctica each spring since 1978 in an area of the ozone layer called the ozone hole. Two scien­tists hypothesize about the cause of the ozone hole.

Scientist 1
Chemicals known as chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs), such as CF2Cl2 and CFCl3, are responsible for the forma­tion of the ozone hole. CFCs have been widely used as refrigerants and aerosol propellants since their introduction in the 1930s. CFCs accumulate in the atmosphere, where solar radiation (Iight) breaks them down to produce chlo­rine atoms (Reaction 1):

(1) CF2Cl2 + light → CF2Cl + Cl

The unstable Cl atoms react with O3 to produce chlorine monoxide and O2 (Reaction 2):

(2) Cl + O3 → ClO + O2

The O2 is then broken down into O atoms (Reaction 3):

(3) O2 + light → 2 O

The unstable O atoms then react with CIO to produce more Cl atoms (Reaction 4):

(4) O + ClO → Cl + O2

Reactions 2-4 make up a chain reaction, because the Cl atoms produced in Reaction 4 can then react with more O3 in Reaction 2:

(2) Cl + O3 → ClO + O2

(3) O2 + light → 2 O

(4) O + ClO → Cl + O2

Thus, the Cl atom produced by 1 CFC molecule can break down large amounts of O3. Due to competing reactions, this chain reaction does gradually stop if the number of Cl atoms produced decreases, but this slowdown takes many years.

Scientist 2
The total amount of O3 in Earth's atmosphere is constant. O3 concentrations vary over Antarctica periodically because wind currents cause local changes in the amounts of all the chemicals in the atmosphere. Though CFCs can break down O3 by Reactions 1-4, the ClO produced in Reaction 2 mostly reacts with the abundant nitrogen oxides in the atmosphere. Reactions 5-7 show how ClO reacts with NO to regenerate O3:

(5) ClO + NO → Cl + NO2

(6) NO2 + light → N + O

(7) O + O2 → O3

ClO can also react with nitrogen dioxide to form chlorine nitrate (Reaction 8):

(8) ClO + NO2 → ClNO3

CINO3 does not react with O3, so it stops the chain reaction shown in Reactions 2-4 from breaking down large amounts of O3.
questions.question: 29.  According to both Scientists 1 and 2, which of the fol­lowing substances must initially be present for CIO to be produced by CFCs in Earth's atmosphere?

choices.A: ClNO3
choices.B: NO
choices.C: NO2
choices.D: O3

questions.question: 31.  A chemist claimed that a molecule of the product in Reaction 8 will have a greater mass than a molecule of either reactant in Reaction 8. Is her claim correct?

choices.A: No; ClO is composed of atoms, not molecules.
choices.B: No; a molecule of ClNO3 has a greater mass than does a molecule of either product.
choices.C: Yes; a molecule of CINO3 has a greater mass than does a molecule of either reactant.
choices.D: Yes; a molecule of CIO has a greater mass than does a molecule of NO2.

questions.question: 32.  If all use of CFCs  were stopped, Scientist 1 would most likely predict that which of the following changes would occur in the total amount of Cl-containing compounds   and   the   total amount of O3 in  Earth's atmosphere?

choices.A: The total amounts of both Cl-containing com­pounds and O3 would eventually increase.
choices.B: The total amounts of both Cl-containing com­pounds and O3 would eventually decrease.
choices.C: The total amount of Cl-containing compounds would eventually increase and the total amount of O3 would stop increasing.
choices.D: The total amount of Cl-containing compounds would eventually decrease and the total amount of O3 would stop decreasing.

questions.question: 33.  Scientist 2 would  most strongly disagree  with  which of the following statements about O3 in Earth's atmosphere?

choices.A: Solar radiation plays a role in the decomposition of O3 in Earth's atmosphere.
choices.B: The concentration of O3 over Antarctica varies from season to season.
choices.C: CFCs can react to break down O3.
choices.D: The average concentration of O3 in Earth's atmo­sphere is decreasing.

(8) ClO + NO2 → ClNO3

CINO3 does not react with O3, so it stops the chain reaction shown in Reactions 2-4 from breaking down large amounts of O3.
questions.question: 34.  After examining Scientist 2's hypothesis, Scientist 1 claimed that Reaction 5 would cause further O3 deple­tion. How would Scientist 1 most likely defend this claim?

choices.A: Reaction 5 produces Cl atoms, which can then react with O3 in Reaction 2.
choices.B: Reaction 5 produces CI atoms, which can then react with CF2Cl to produce CF2Cl2.
choices.C: Reaction 5 causes the amount of ClO to decrease, so little O3 can be regenerated.
choices.D: Reaction 5 causes  the amount  of  NO  to decrease, so not enough NO2 can be produced for Reaction 6.

questions.title: Passage Ⅵ
questions.article:
Ozone (O3) is concentrated in a part of Earth's atmo­sphere called the ozone layer. O3 absorbs harmful high­-energy solar radiation. Unusually low amounts of O3 have been detected over Antarctica each spring since 1978 in an area of the ozone layer called the ozone hole. Two scien­tists hypothesize about the cause of the ozone hole.

Scientist 1
Chemicals known as chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs), such as CF2Cl2 and CFCl3, are responsible for the forma­tion of the ozone hole. CFCs have been widely used as refrigerants and aerosol propellants since their introduction in the 1930s. CFCs accumulate in the atmosphere, where solar radiation (Iight) breaks them down to produce chlo­rine atoms (Reaction 1):

(1) CF2Cl2 + light → CF2Cl + Cl

The unstable Cl atoms react with O3 to produce chlorine monoxide and O2 (Reaction 2):

(2) Cl + O3 → ClO + O2

The O2 is then broken down into O atoms (Reaction 3):

(3) O2 + light → 2 O

The unstable O atoms then react with CIO to produce more Cl atoms (Reaction 4):

(4) O + ClO → Cl + O2

Reactions 2-4 make up a chain reaction, because the Cl atoms produced in Reaction 4 can then react with more O3 in Reaction 2:

(2) Cl + O3 → ClO + O2

(3) O2 + light → 2 O

(4) O + ClO → Cl + O2

Thus, the Cl atom produced by 1 CFC molecule can break down large amounts of O3. Due to competing reactions, this chain reaction does gradually stop if the number of Cl atoms produced decreases, but this slowdown takes many years.

Scientist 2
The total amount of O3 in Earth's atmosphere is constant. O3 concentrations vary over Antarctica periodically because wind currents cause local changes in the amounts of all the chemicals in the atmosphere. Though CFCs can break down O3 by Reactions 1-4, the ClO produced in Reaction 2 mostly reacts with the abundant nitrogen oxides in the atmosphere. Reactions 5-7 show how ClO reacts with NO to regenerate O3:

(5) ClO + NO → Cl + NO2

(6) NO2 + light → N + O

(7) O + O2 → O3

ClO can also react with nitrogen dioxide to form chlorine nitrate (Reaction 8):

(8) ClO + NO2 → ClNO3

CINO3 does not react with O3, so it stops the chain reaction shown in Reactions 2-4 from breaking down large amounts of O3.
questions.question: 35.  In which of the following ways could Reaction 8 in Scientist 2's hypothesis contradict Scientist 1's hypoth­esis? The chain reaction  shown  in Reactions  2-4  will not occur if all of the:

choices.A: ClO produced in Reaction 2 reacts with NO2.
choices.B: CIO produced in Reaction 4 reacts with NO.
choices.C: NO2 produced in Reaction 5 reacts with light.
choices.D: NO2 produced in Reaction 8 reacts with ClO.

questions.title: Passage Ⅶ
questions.article:
Ferromagnetic materials become magnetic when they are placed in an external magnetic field.

Figures 1 and 2 are graphs of the total magnetic field, B, versus the intensity of the external magnetic field, H, for Materials X and Y, respectively. (B = µ0 [M + H], where µ0 is a constant and M is the magnetization of the material.) B varies as H is increased from zero, then decreased, then increased again, as shown by the directions of the arrows in the figures. If B is not zero when H returns to zero, a material has been magnetized.

When B or H is positive(negative), it is described as pointing north(south).
questions.question: 36.  For Material X, the maximum positive value of B was obtained at an H closest to:

choices.A: +100 amperes/meter.
choices.B: +200 amperes/meter.
choices.C: +300 amperes/meter.
choices.D: +400 amperes/meter.

questions.question: 40.  Consider the most positive value of B and the most negative value of B on the graph in Figure 1. How are these two values of B related? The most negative value of B is equal to:

choices.A: -1 times the most positive value of B.
choices.B: +1 times the most positive value of B.
choices.C: -1 divided by the most positive value of B.
choices.D: +1 divided by the most positive value of B.
